title.narrative: Capacity building program for state of the art technologies of Nutritional Intake, Status and Physical activity Assessment (NISPA)

description.narrative: Capacity building program for state of the art technologies of Nutritional Intake, Status and Physical activity Assessment (NISPA)

The lack of validated and standardised methodologies to perform dietary assessment, as well as the paucity of nationally representative micronutrient status and dietary intake data in Africa is a relevant and known problem. The aims of the proposed training workshops are to apply novel techniques in assessing dietary intake as well as measuring micronutrient status and physical activity for building capacity in a large African network spanning 39 African countries. Furthermore, the planned training courses are aiming at providing technologies and tools to build monitoring, surveillance, and food testing capacity within both public and private sectors. The objective of the training programme are to develop hands-on e-learning resources relevant for nutrition researchers, the food industry, government as well as food and health authorities. To enable the project to deliver these aims, e-learning courses will be developed in 3 face-to-face training courses in collaboration with the Centre of Excellence for Nutrition (CEN) at North-West University and the Lodestar Centre of Excellence network of knowledge transfer and training centres in South Africa. The network aims to develop e-learning tools for nutritional intake, status and physical activity measurement with relevance to both networks using state of the art methodologies. Newcastle University will coordinate the training workshops in collaboration with Craft Nutrition Consulting (USA) and the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna due to existing expertise in dietary intake, nutritional status and physical activity measurement. The courses will be running between 2-5 days and will cover nutritional intake assessment using online tools (Intake24) and tablet based 24h assessments, nutritional status determination using finger prick blood samples combined with robust laboratory micronutrient assessments, the assessment of energy expenditure using isotope dilution techniques and the measurement of physical activity using the Axivity accelerometer. The e-learning courses will be developed after face-to-face meetings in year 1 for subsequent years. Course material will either be given 100% online, or in a combination of online and on-site courses depending on demand and resources. The training course addresses the GCRF challenge area of ‘sustainable health and wellbeing’.
